pages.title: Week 4 - Decision Trees, Random Forest, XGBoost

elements.content: [[h3]]Decision Trees[[/]]

➔ Consider this scenario: you are a doctor and a person walks in to your hospital with a lot of different symptoms. Your job is to diagnose what disease they have. What is the most efficient way to do this?
➔ One way to do this would be to make a tree considering potential combinations
[[h3]]What is a Decision Tree?[[/]]
➔ A branching diagram that represents choices to get to a final result
➔ Usually, we try to solve some problem in ML with a huge tree
➔ Can be used for regression and classification(clustering) tasks
[[h3]]Why use them?[[/]]
➔ Simple to understand, you can easily view them as a branching tree
➔ Can handle many kinds of data including numerical and categorical data
➔ Forces an outcome to be formed, never returns a null prediction
[[h3]]Some reasons NOT to use them[[/]]
➔ Data is often overfit and can cause issues especially if the training data has noise
➔ Low bias makes the tree hard to use with new data
➔ Training time is often larger, which may be a big problem for costs and feasibility on larger datasets

pages.title: Week 4 - Decision Trees, Random Forest, XGBoost

elements.content: [[h3]]Random Forest[[/]]
➔ Used to solve both regression and classification tasks
➔ Uses many decision trees (hence forest) and takes their average to make predictions
➔ The more the trees, the more accurate Random Forest is
➔ Eradicates limitations of decision trees, prevents overfitting and increases precision
[[h3]]Methods[[/]]
➔ Instead of determining where the tree splits, Random Forest uses randomness to generate each order of nodes where the tree splits
➔ Example: To decide whether to buy something, 4 factors affect the buyers decision
➔ RF will generate many trees with random permutations of those 4 factors as different trees, the highest voted decision (buy or don’t buy) will be picked

pages.title: Week 4 - Decision Trees, Random Forest, XGBoost

elements.content: [[h3]]XGBoost[[/]]
➔ “Extreme Gradient Boost” helps improve and speed up decision trees through a process called gradient boosting.
➔ Hugely popular in modern machine learning tasks, this has been dominating competitions where tabulated/structured data is present.
[[h3]]Methods[[/]]
➔ The inner workings of XGBoost are based on the gradient boost algorithm
➔ Gradient boost uses the average of the target “y” values to make the first prediction, and then makes trees based on errors in that prediction by calculating an error gradient
➔ Over time, each tree gets better at predicting the result

pages.title: Week 4 - Decision Trees, Random Forest, XGBoost

elements.content: [[h3]]Summary[[/]]
➔ “By using Decision Trees, we can do a variety of machine learning tasks through many different methods
➔ While decision trees by themselves are often accurate, Random Forest and Extreme Gradient Boost often outperform them
➔ The parameters in a project matter a lot, try changing them up and searching up how you can make this more effective!
